review.title: Automatic Anomaly Detection in the Cloud Via Statistical Learning
review.abstract: Performance and high availability have become increasingly important drivers, amongst other drivers, for user retention in the context of web services such as social networks, and web search. Exogenic and/or endogenic factors often give rise to anomalies, making it very challenging to maintain high availability, while also delivering high performance. Given that service-oriented architectures (SOA) typically have a large number of services, with each service having a large set of metrics, automatic detection of anomalies is non-trivial.

metadata.title: Automatic Anomaly Detection in the Cloud Via Statistical Learning

sections.text: To this end, we developed two novel statistical techniques to automatically detect anomalies in cloud infrastructure data. Specifically, these techniques use statistical learning to detect anomalies in both application and system metrics. Seasonal decomposition is used to filter the trend and seasonal components of time series, followed by the use of robust statistical metrics - mean and mean absolute deviation (MAD) - to accurately detect anomalies, even at seasonal peaks. We demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed techniques from three different perspectives: capacity planning, user behavior, and supervised learning. Specifically, we have used production data for evaluation, and we report on precision, recall, and F measurement in each case.

sections.heading: 3. TECHNIQUES
sections.text: In this section, we explain our approaches Seasonal ESD (SESD) and Seasonal Hybrid ESD (S-H-ESD). Note that both approaches are currently used to automatically detect anomalies in production data on a daily basis. We used an incremental approach to develop both approaches. In particular, we started by evaluating the "rule of thumb" (the three sigma rule) against production data and gradually learned the limitations of using existing techniques to automatically detect anomalies in production data. In the rest of this section, we will guide the reader through the key steps of our incremental approach mentioned above.

sections.text: As discussed in the previous section, Twitter data (from production) has a severe seasonality. In most cases, the underlying distribution has a multimodal distribution, as illustrated in Figure 4. This limits the applicability of existing anomaly detection techniques such as grubbs and ESD, since existing techniques require normal data distribution. Specifically, we have learned that the presence of multiple modes results in a higher value of standard deviation (the increase can be up to 5%), which in turn masks some of the "true" anomalies. To this end, we use time series that break down, using a particular time series (X) into three - seasonal (SX), trends (TX) and residual components (RX) - components that exhibit an unimodal distribution of values based on the application of anomalous detection methods.

sections.text: Seasonal hybrid ESD (S-H-ESD) builds on the S-ESD algorithm described in the previous subsection to provide a more consistent measurement of the central tendency of a time series with a high percentage of anomalies. Consider, for example, the time series shown in Figure 8a. From the figure, we find that the seasonal component is obvious in the middle region of the time series, but a significant portion of the time series is anomalous, which can inflate the mean and standard deviation, resulting in real anomalies being marked as non-anomalous and thus producing a high number of false negatives. sections.heading: 4. EVALUATION
sections.text: In this section, we outline our methodology for evaluating the proposed techniques, discuss their use in production and, last but not least, present results to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed techniques.

sections.heading: 4.1 Methodology
sections.text: The effectiveness of S-ESD and S-H-ESD was evaluated against a broad corpus of time series data from production, which corresponded to both low system ratios and higher core ratios (business ratios).For example, the following ratios were used, but not limited to: r System Metricsz CPU utilizationz Heap usagez Time spent in GC (Garbage Collection) z Disk writesr Application Metricsz Request Latencyr Core Driversz Tweets per minute (TPM) z Retweets per minute (RTPM) z Unique Photos Per minute (UPPM) More than 20 data sets were used for evaluation, ranging from two-week periods to four-week periods with hours of granularity.

sections.heading: 4.2 Production
sections.text: Increasingly, machine-generated BigData is being used to increase the performance and efficiency of data centers / cloud computing platforms. BigData is often characterized by volume and speed [43, 44]. Given the variety of services in our Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) and the fact that each service monitors a large number of metrics, it is imperative to automatically detect anomalies 2 in the time series of each metric. We have used the proposed techniques to automatically detect anomalies in production data for a wide range of services. It is also possible to set a threshold to refine the amount of anomalies detected (using the proposed techniques) based on the specific requirements of the service owner. For example, a manual approach from a cost perspective would be prohibitive and would also be possible for capacity engineers to set a threshold so that only anomalies greater than the specified threshold are displayed.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we introduced two novel statistical techniques for automatically detecting anomalies in cloud infrastructure data. Although there is a large research group for detecting anomalies, the seasonal (and trendy) nature of cloud infrastructure data limits the application of techniques. To this end, we proposed a method called SeasonalESD (S-ESD), which combines seasonal decomposition and the generalized ESD test for detecting anomalies. The second method, Seasonal Hybrid ESD (S-H-ESD), builds on SESD to allow for a robust anomaly when a significant proportion (up to 50%) of the underlying data is anomalous. This is achieved by extending the original ESD algorithm with robust statistical measures, median and median absolute deviations (MAD). The effectiveness of both the Seasonal-9 as well as the ESD-2D was performed using both ESD and ESD-2D.

metadata.abstractText: Performance and high availability have become increasingly important drivers, amongst other drivers, for user retention in the context of web services such as social networks, and web search. Exogenic and/or endogenic factors often give rise to anomalies, making it very challenging to maintain high availability, while also delivering high performance. Given that service-oriented architectures (SOA) typically have a large number of services, with each service having a large set of metrics, automatic detection of anomalies is nontrivial. Although there exists a large body of prior research in anomaly detection, existing techniques are not applicable in the context of social network data, owing to the inherent seasonal and trend components in the time series data. To this end, we developed two novel statistical techniques for automatically detecting anomalies in cloud infrastructure data. Specifically, the techniques employ statistical learning to detect anomalies in both application, and system metrics. Seasonal decomposition is employed to filter the trend and seasonal components of the time series, followed by the use of robust statistical metrics – median and median absolute deviation (MAD) – to accurately detect anomalies, even in the presence of seasonal spikes. We demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed techniques from three different perspectives, viz., capacity planning, user behavior, and supervised learning. In particular, we used production data for evaluation, and we report Precision, Recall, and F-measure in each case.
